comments: I get 13+ failures when running all tests.
I'll investigate why testJiraFilterRefresh hangs.

This is due to changes to the query synchronization which now primes all query hits. I am not yet conviced that that is a good idea.

I have deleted all tasks from the test repository to make the tests work again. 

I'll take care of the failing test case in JiraRpcClientTest.

Down to 4 errors and 8 failures now. I'll take a look at the Trac tests and WebClientUtilTest.

Eugene, could you run and fix the Jira tests?
I'll take a look at two failing Task List integration tests tomorrow or Thurssday.

(In reply to comment #3)
> Down to 4 errors and 8 failures now. I'll take a look at the Trac tests and
> WebClientUtilTest.
> Eugene, could you run and fix the Jira tests?

I looked at some failures, but jira server at mylar.eclipse.org is incredibly slow and some tests failed with sockedtimeout errors. Can you please export its configuration and email it to me, so I can run it locally?

I tweaked "My tests" named query to only return issues created in last 10 minutes.

To fix JiraRepositoryConnectorTest.testUpdateTask() failure we need to add some permissions to test account so it would be able to retrieve list of editable fields.

> I looked at some failures, but jira server at mylar.eclipse.org is incredibly
> slow and some tests failed with sockedtimeout errors. Can you please export its
> configuration and email it to me, so I can run it locally?

You should be able to export the database as the admin user.

> To fix JiraRepositoryConnectorTest.testUpdateTask() failure we need to add some
> permissions to test account so it would be able to retrieve list of editable
> fields.

There are multiple users with different permissions. PrivilegeLevel.USER should provide you with a user that is in the jira-dev group and should have sufficient permissions.

(In reply to comment #6)
> You should be able to export the database as the admin user.

I know, but I can't download that exported file. It is saved on the server.

> > To fix JiraRepositoryConnectorTest.testUpdateTask() failure we need to add
> > some permissions to test account so it would be able to retrieve list of
> > editable fields.
> 
> There are multiple users with different permissions. PrivilegeLevel.USER
> should provide you with a user that is in the jira-dev group and should have
> sufficient permissions.

I'll have to check that...
I have fixes for a number of failing bugzilla tests in my workspace.  Will commit soon.

I committed fixes for failing jira tests.

Steffen, there is SubstitutionTextReader.LINE_DELIM constant that could be platform specific. I hardcoded it for now, but we may need to keep an eye on it.

Created an attachment (id=70464)
mylar/context/zip

I have fixed the URLs for Trac and JIRA to point to the new vserver name. TracWebClientTest.validate010() fails intermittently, I look into that.

Eugene, we can not use PrivilegeLevel.ADMIN in tests that are run as part of the suite since we do not want to distribute that password. 

I get 12 errors and 15 failures total now.
Fixed a few more bugzilla and task tests. We're getting there!

(In reply to comment #11)
> Eugene, we can not use PrivilegeLevel.ADMIN in tests that are run as part of
> the suite since we do not want to distribute that password. 

The only alternative is to hardcode custom field ids. But then we need to automate creation of jira instances, perhaps use in-process cargo + tomcat + jira-in-a-war + import static configuration.

Having hard-coded ids is acceptable and that is how it is done for Trac. Anybody needs to be able to run the test-suite and we only have a single license so there is no alternative to running it on the server.

Created an attachment (id=72099)
test errors from running AllTracTests suite

I always get a few errors and sometimes failures as well when running AllTracTests, but each time the errors came from different test cases. So I'm not sure whether it is an issue of my network connection. 

Attached is the failure list from a latest run.

I haven't seen time out failures ("The host did not accept the connection within timeout of 30000
ms") on my end. Did anyone else ever get failures like that when running the test suite?

Framework tests are all passing now. Steffen, Eugene, I'm still seeing some JIRA failures. If these pass when run standalone or understood but don't have time, consider commenting out with XXX and addressing at later date so we can get back the green bar.

JiraFilterTest.testCustomQuery and a couple others are dying due to JiraServiceUnavailableException
JiraRepositoryConnectorTest.testUpdateTask failing with invalid issue date
I just ran AllJiraTests without getting failures. JiraServiceUnavailableException could have been caused by an intermittent server error or did you already disable the tests?
Yup, must have been network errors. Just JiraRepositoryConnectorTest.testUpdateTask is failing with invalid issue date (line 162).

After some investigation with Rob it seems like JiraRepositoryConnectorTest.testUpdateTask() failure is related to the time zone. Rob is 3 hours behind and both Steffen and I are in the same TZ as server that is in Ottawa if I am not mistaken... I'll have to check what we can do about that since due date field is truncated to day upon submission, but we do get back value with hours in the rss.

In order to get the test suite to go and stay green I have commented out the problematic assertions in JiraRepositoryConnectorText.testUpdateTask().  Each missing assertion has a XXX before it.  These should be put back before this bug is closed.
Fixed time zone related stuff and uncommented assertions.
Great.  A Java refactoring test has been failing intermittently for me.  Will investigate.

Tests failing again, will use this to track resolution.
As per conference call we will not reopen this bug report but rather open new bugs targeting the specific points of failure.

I have found that some of the tests create BugzillaClient directly, not by using BugzillaClientFactory (for example BugzillaConfigurationTest). By that reason they do not favour my proxy settings, and, therefore, fail with ConnectionTimeout exception. The question is - is it safe to replace such constructors with factories and how do you see them fixed? Will I create a patch for this? I ask it since this is a test change and it is not covered by another test.

The trick here is that clients are cached so you may not be getting an updated client when requesting one unless TaskRepositoryManager.notifyRepositorySettingsChanged(changedRepository) is called. You could construct a utility method that just issues this notification then gets a new client. A patch would be good.

Created an attachment (id=78569)
Fixed bugzilla tests to honor platform proxy settings

Created an attachment (id=78570)
mylyn/context/zip
Patch applied.  Thanks Jevgeni!
